papers.title: Didactic Drama: ‘Everyman’ and other Morality Plays
papers.abstract: The first records of Morality plays, of which the most widely known is Everyman, occur at around the same time as the Mystery Cycles were being performed by the trade guilds. It is at first easier to see the differences between the two types of play rather than their similarities. The Morality is not concerned with Bible history and is not cyclical in form. Nevertheless, both forms are unashamedly didactic drama and both are deeply concerned for the spiritual welfare of man. Because the Morality was not tied to the static theology of the scriptures which shaped the Mystery play, it is in many ways a more flexible dramatic form. The driving force behind any Morality play was to teach — but the personal views of the author (most usually an unknown writer) towards social, political, religious or moral matters were incorporated into a set of conventions which that writer in turn both inherited and expanded. For this reason there is no such thing as a 'typical' Morality play — a fact which is at the same time both exhilarating and exasperating.

papers.title: The Ethical Content of the Face-to-Face
papers.abstract: The first things to remember about the face-to-face encounter between the self and the other person are that it is concrete and particular. It is not an idea or concept, nor a type of action or event. It is a concrete reality, an event; it occurs. Furthermore, it occurs as utterly particular: the self is a particular person, and the face-of-the-other is a particular revelation of a particular person. What is occluded, hidden, or forgotten in our ordinary lives is not some idea or value; it is this presence of the other's face to me – and my responsibility to and for this person. Moreover, this reality or event or encounter, which in a sense is beyond our thinking, our concepts, and our rules, and prior to them, is determinative and unconditional. It is all plea and command, made again and again, in episode after episode. It is not like a single clash that occurred sometime in the past and that is heard only in its continuing echoes; it is more like echoes themselves always present without any such crash or origin.

papers.title: Perfectionism, value pluralism, and the human good
papers.abstract: What makes for a good life? If you have a child, a spouse, or a very close friend you probably want what is best for her. However, in order to know what would be best for your loved one you need an account of the personal good. I argue for a version of value pluralism, according to which there is disparate list of fundamental goods which resist reduction to some single supervalue such as pleasure and lack any strong unifying principle. I argue that any adequate account of the human good must include pleasure and freedom from pain, knowledge and understanding, practical rationality, and proper emotional responsiveness as fundamental goods, and that the only thing these various goods have in common is their intrinsic goodness. Value pluralism is an alternative to various kinds of monism about the good, such as hedonism, perfectionism, and the desire-satisfaction theory. Hedonism explains the value of any putative good in terms of pleasure, while perfectionism sees the good in terms of the development and exercise of those capacities or characteristics essential to some aspect of our nature. Desire- satisfaction views are best considered a form of monism about the good, since their identification of one's good with the satisfaction of one's desires offers a way of unifying various goods. The battle between monistic and pluralistic accounts is usefully analyzed in terms of competing theoretical virtues such as unity, simplicity, explanatory coherence, and plausibility. Monistic accounts typically score high along the first three of these dimensions and quite low along the last. I consider what I take to be the most promising versions of value monism, and argue that each scores so low along the dimension of plausibility that it should be rejected in favor of value pluralism. I begin by considering hedonism and the desire- satisfaction view and then discuss two distinct versions of perfectionism. Hedonism and perfectionism, in particular, are implausible because they fail to recognize our complex natures as embodied rational agents, and our need for a vision of the good which is correspondingly complex. In the final chapter I offer just such an account

papers.title: &quot;God Has No Allergies&quot;: Immanent Ethics and the Simulacra of the Immune System
papers.abstract: “God has No Allergies”: Immanent Ethics and the Simulacra of the Immune System Adrian Mackenzie “[T]he science of life always accommodates a philosophy of life.”1 Conventional approaches to bioethics long for a purified set of principles in order to guide the application of scientific knowledges of the body — the life sciences — to individual “cases.” In the realm of bioethics, the possibility that these knowledges might themselves constitute entities such as the individual, or the possibility that the individual body might itself be something other than the more or less governable a-historical object of technoscientific action, awakens a kind of horror autotoxicus. Nor do the prevalent modes of ethical discourse react kindly to the possibility that the “living” body of an individual is also a self, an actor within a complicated set of narratives, codes and apparatuses whose various registers — medical, economic, racial, sexual, religious, and so on — intersect. In short, conventional bioethical discourses refuse to acknowledge that, as Emmanual Levinas has written, “the body is a permanent contestation of the prerogative attributed to consciousness of ‘giving meaning’ to each thing; it lives as this contestation.”2 Traditional bioethics disappoints us insofar as it overlooks the ways the body contests the prerogatives of consciousness, contests reason and self-identity. Instead of opening onto the possibility of divergent ethea, bioethics’ universalizing adjudicative principles legitimate the biomedical normalization of differences by trying to deal only with the moral rights of the rational self and by leaving the differing character of embodiment — a most profound aspect of the ethical habitat — aside. In its separation of scientific theory and “ethical” practice, and in its unwillingness to transit any borders into the epistemological territory of science, conventional bioethics misapprehends the active and ambivalent role of technoscientific intervention, an intervention which both produces these crucial differences in embodiment and participates in their effacement. Traditional bioethics allergically responds to the ethical issue — the maintenance of ethos, of embodied differences, of the character and habits of individual bodies. Bios: nomó “Now it is over life, throughout its unfolding, that power establishes its dominion.”3 Foucault’s well-known description of a shift during the last two centuries from sovereign to disciplinary power or “bio-power” implies a displacement in the substance of ethics.4 In diverse discourses and domains, it becomes increasingly obvious that the presumed exclusion of ethics from the theoretical-pragmatic complex of science itself, from the very concrete operations and forces of technoscientific discourses engaging living bodies, significantly limits the relevance and effectiveness of the traditional notion of ethics.5 As Donna Haraway describes it, “the power of biomedical language . . . for shaping the unequal experience of sickness and death for millions is a social fact deriving from on-going heterogeneous social processes.” 6 The morality-displacing power of biomedical discourse and practice does not confine itself to sickness and death, but branches out into the normalization of whole populations. At many different scales and under different aspects — birth, death, sexual relations, work, fitness, stress, leisure, and so on — life is targeted by the vectors of biomedical intervention. Again, Foucault makes this point succinctly when he writes of the emergence of bio-power: “For the first time in history, no doubt, biological existence was reflected in political existence; the fact of living was no longer an inaccessible substrate that only emerged from time to time; amid the randomness of death and its fatality; part of it passed into knowledge’s field of control and power’s sphere of intervention.”7 The propagation of bio-power — designating “what brought life and its mechanisms into the realm of explicit calculation and made knowledge-power an agent of transformation of human life”8 — powerfully challenges any responsive ethics to address the realm of physiology and to reframe the ethical substance to include the embodiment of biomedical materiality. In other words, so-called “physiological” or “biological” questions increasingly raise ethical issues in ways that cannot be disentangled from the historical conditions of life as a locus of power relations or, conversely, solved through an a-historical ethico-moral calculus. Under the auspices of bio-power, biological knowledge increasingly presents itself as the ground of self-realization and governance...

papers.title: Sleep and Its Disorders
papers.abstract: IT may be taken as axiomatic that the greatest satisfaction in living comes to those fortunate people who early develop good habits-good habits in the maintenance of bodily economy, thinking, fancy, emotional control. This lesson learned early cements a partnership between the I and its bodily functioning so that neither obtrudes itself on the other or dominates the partnership in an unwholesome way. Especially fortunate is the person who takes his ordinary bodily workings for granted, has confidence in their support, and so remains free to investigate the boundless opportunities in life. These considerations apply to any type of bodily working and so we may look at the question of sleep from this standpoint.

papers.title: Asymmetry in the estimation of interpersonal distance and identity affirmation
papers.abstract: Abstract An asymmetry effect is known to exist in the estimation of interpersonal distance, depending on whether the point of reference for the estimation is the subject (‘How far are the others from you?’) or the others How far are you from the others?). It looks as though, through the effect of a self‐centring schema, subjects feel that others occupy their own space more than they occupy the space of others. A self‐centring schema has also been found in many other processes involving judgment or comparison of oneself and others. It is generally interpreted as a sign of the affirmation and defence of personal identity. The three experiments reported here attempt to relate the asymmetries in the distances perceived between persons represented on a map to the following three areas in which one's sense of personal or group identity is involved: (1) in the perception of one's own specificity with respect to others (or of the specificity of the group to which one belongs with respect to other groups) (experiment 1), (2) in one's ability to put oneself in the place of others (exocentrism) (experiment 2). and (3) in the individuation of oneself by others (experiment 3). The results of these three experiments lead us to believe that it is indeed the processes of identification and affirmation of personal and group identity ‐ along with the underlying categorization processes — that are the source of the asymmetries observed in interpersonal distance estimation. The consistency of the data obtained in different situations also validates the technique used for estimating interpersonal distance.

papers.title: Contemplation and new lifestyles (or how to promote your personal development from a hospital bed)
papers.abstract: The word contemplation almost always immediately conjures up thoughts of great silences and vast open spaces, or of small, closed environments designed for intense, concentrated thought.The latter settings, often religious, barely furnished and dimly lit, are conducive to introspection and an opening of the soul to positive thoughts, pregnant with the desire for peace, and often goodness.Contemplative thought is tinged with a certain religiosity that is not necessarily linked to a specific religious denomination but rather to one's own "inner self", which may even be open to the possibility of encountering and discovering the "other" (not always with a small "o"): an encounter rich with novelty, when it comes to desires at least, and therefore just waiting to be discovered.But such discovery, to come about, practically always demands, as a necessary condition, a climate of humilitya state of being that is not always easy to achieve but that, over time, can be attained, providing one manages to avoid the affectation that is the opposite of the natural, lightly worn humility to which we aspire.Humility, like the contemplative state, is not something that can be improvised.Humility is a gift that life gives us: a gift to be sought, loved and protected.Contemplation is possible for those seeking spaces for their soul -those wanting to open up their mind and their heart.And for all this to be possible, a crucial factor is place, which is to be understood not only in a physical sense.Being "in the right place" means being in a conducive atmosphere, and this necessary condition can manifest itself at the most unexpected times: the language of the spirit comes not so much from that which surrounds us as from within.It may seem strange -and I am the papers.title: EKOLOGIJA, ZAŠTITA OKOLIŠA .Ontološko–etički vidik
papers.abstract: A man has become, affecting all fundamental happenings, that take place in biosphere, one of the most important environmental factors. His activity is in most cases without obeying rhythms in nature, uncoordinated with it, destructive for life, ecosystems and biosphere on the whole. The development of technique and technology has put an important question for a man of how to protect nature and himself from negative consequence of technical and technological progress. Human activity regularly depends on the essence of a man, and not only to do or to have. Not a single action would produce a permanent success without ethical awareness and conscience, therefore it is to no purpose to search solutions only out of moral sphere. A man is also responsible for all non-rational beings on the Earth; he has to live and act in accordance with nature and its laws; does not have the moral right to do all that is to him physically possible, and the profit cannot be the only goal of economy. It is not only that our and future generations have the right to live, we cannot deny it to them. On these obligations all states have to care, all societies and all legislatures (national and international)

papers.title: Foundations of a General Ethics: Selves, Sentient Beings, and Other Responsively Cohesive Structures
papers.abstract: Everything we can refer to – physical, biological, psychological, or a human-created entity, institution, activity, or expression of some kind, and whether constituted of brute physical stuff or less tangible complexes of social arrangements, ideas, images, movements, and so on – can be considered in terms of its form of organization or structure. This applies even if what we want to say about these things is that they represent a disorganized or unstructured example of their kind or else that they simply lack any discernible form of internal organization or structure in the sense that their internal structure is undifferentiated or homogenous as opposed to being ‘all over the place’. We therefore live in a world in which everything can be characterized, either positively or negatively, in terms of its form of organization or structure. (The terms ‘form of organization’ and ‘structure’ can be used interchangeably in the context of this paper, although I will tend to use the term ‘structure’ in what follows.)

papers.title: Artificially Natural: A Brief History of Modern Sport
papers.abstract: Sport is designed, and in being designed, is artificial. Seeing sport in this way suggests that athlete's moving bodies are engaged in unnatural activity. If sport was a natural, rational practice, if it was not designed, planned and constructed in a particular way with particular ends, rugby players would be able to throw the ball forward to a member of their own team, and we would not need qualifications in advanced mathematics to determine a golf handicap, or to recalculate the length of an innings in one-day cricket that has been shortened by rain. To say that sport is designed is not to argue that sport developed with a plan and intended outcome, but merely to recognize that sport's artificiality is the characteristic that sets it apart from play; it is rule bound, controlled, organized, disciplined, and managed. It is also intensely historicized: around the world large numbers of people spend incalculable amounts of energy dealing with issues that are the product of historical awareness of sports. Records are kept, aesthetics are debated, and rivalries are played out across generations. Paradoxically, popular and scholarly historical understandings of sport tend to obscure its artificiality, in large part because sport is so important in the now: the challenge in thinking historically about sport design is to get beyond a sense that there has been an inexorable series of logical steps towards the present. This chapter places sport's artificiality in a historical context through a discussion of the design of sport's rules and organizations, its spaces and equipment, including athletes' bodies, and the long-standing inter-relationship between sport and various media formations.

papers.title: Hawthorne and Reform
papers.abstract: But there is still another view, and probably as wise a one. It looks upon slavery as one of those evils which divine Providence does not leave to be remedied by human contrivances, but which, in its own good time, by some means impossible to be anticipated, but of the simplest and easiest operation, when all its uses shall have been fulfilled, it causes to vanish like a dream. There is no instance, in all history, of the human will and intellect having perfected any great moral reform by methods which it adapted to that end; but the progress of the world, at every step, leaves some evil or wrong on the path behind it, which the wisest of mankind, of their own set purpose, could never have found the way to rectify.2

papers.title: Obligation and Control
papers.abstract: One cannot perform an act that is morally right, wrong, or obligatory if one does not have appropriate control over that act; deontic acts presuppose control. This is, perhaps, most evident in the case of moral obligation. It is difficult to accept the verdict that Leno, though pinned to his seat, ought to have saved the child, or that the paraplegic ought to have walked across the lawn when 'ought' denotes moral obligation or requirement. Again, it is hard to see how Mitch did something that is morally wrong by failing to help the victim of the car crash when he could not have helped the victim. Or it is, minimally, puzzling to see how Zakir did moral wrong by stealing the loaf when he could not but have stolen it. One might, given apt circumstances, reasonably think that Zakir did something bad by stealing the loaf, but this judgment is consistent with Zakir's not having done wrong. Or, again, it is paradoxical to suppose that the mother's not spanking the child was morally right when she literally lacked the ability to spank her child. These enigmas are not merely pragmatic or do not simply have to do with substantive moral claims about what is fair but are conceptual; the verdict about the paraplegic, for instance, seems conceptually inconsistent. Such examples, and numerous others like them, motivate the view that one cannot do what is right, or wrong, or obligatory unless one has appropriate "deontic-grounding control" over what one does.

papers.title: The science of taste
papers.abstract: pelled to acknowledge a far greater uniformity of appreciation than we are apt to suppose from the frequent use of such phrases as that " tastes are so various as to be beyond the influence of rational dis- cussion."It often happens that a man likes one thing before his attention is directed to another, just as he may relish one dish until he partakes of a better.Devise, however, something essentially good, some- thing which satisfies the common yearnings of civilized humanity, and it will as surely court universal appro- bation as the skill of the accomplished chef will elicit general commendation.No better illustration of popular misconception can here be adduced than that treated of in Chapter IV.A friend rejoicing in the glories of the imagination, or aiming at discovering artistic proficiency alone, triumphantly points to a ceiling embellished with sky, clouds, doves, and angels, and exultingly exclaims, "Is not this fine !" You cannot go into ecstasies over it ; you feel it ought not to be there.You essay your reasons ; he will not listen to reasons.He shrugs his shoulders, pities your want of appreciation, and cuts short all controversy by giving you to understand that disapproval is immaterial, because whether you like it or do not like it is entirely a question of " taste."Such decoration is radically wrong, since a house being a purely artificial thing, and a roof an absolutely neces- sary thing, no attempt should be made to impart to the ceiling a semblance of intangibility, or to suggest ex- posure to the open air.The friend can assign no reason for his approval beyond the circumstance that he likes it, and when he tells you it is a matter of "taste," he really means that the thing he admires suits his own predisposition.Now Taste, as contradistinguished from predilec- tion, is eminently a subject within the influence of rational discussion.It will not be long before prin- ciples are established in this as in every other science ; and if we deduce our rules from those ascertainable laws written upon the open volume of Nature before us, we shall have no difficulty in ascertaining what is best calculated to please the eye, gratify the mind, elevate the sentiments, and conduce to that general harmony which prevails in creation around us ; which the spirit of man so earnestly desires, but which the folly of man so materially impedes.But it is idle to expect any effectual progress in popular appreciation unless we bear in mind the dis- tinction already adverted to between rules and principles ; unless we treat the subject more as a matter of judgment than of mere sentiment ; unless attention be drawn to the why and wherefore of aesthetic proposi- tions.It would be difficult to name even any book which goes beyond telling us that we ought to admire this, that, or the other, without assigning any reason for doing so; or that we ought to adopt one thing and B 2 ment ; that the arch is supposed to have been unknown to them, and to have been introduced only after the Macedonian conquest, -although recent discoveries in Asia Minor somewhat militate against this hypo- thesis ; -that it forms a distinguishing feature in Eoman design ; that it is a vast improvement upon the rigid lines of their predecessors, and that it is an in- dispensable element in successful construction at the present day.After the transfer of the capital to Byzantium oriental extravagances became engrafted upon the grand simplicity of the Eoman style, and thence arose the Byzantine, a very good specimen of which, although somewhat fantastic, is afforded in the Cathedral of St. Mark's in Venice.The twelfth century witnessed the incipience of that most exquisite method known as the Gothic, with its pointed arch and steeple, its buttresses, its mullion windows, chamfered edges, foliations, delicate tracery, and exquisite elaborations.From its almost simul- taneous adoption by those nations which had taken part in the Crusades, the germs of this style are supposed to have been borrowed from the Saracens ; and certainly there is a striking resemblance in the shape of the arch, in the spires, and in other salient characteristics.In the South Kensington Museum is a photograph from an unfinished mausoleum to Ali Adil Shah, which bears a most remarkable similitude to that of a ruined abbey.

papers.title: Nothing (and Something)
papers.abstract: The social world, particularly in the realm of consumption, is increasingly characterized by nothing. The large numbers of people in many other countries are now using credit cards and in much the same everyday way that Americans have for decades. This chapter exemplifies the global expansion of this relatively empty form-one that gains much of its substance in actual use. The phenomena of focal concern in the chapter exist at or near the nothing end of the continuum; all phenomena exist somewhere between the extremes of the nothing-something poles of the continuum. The distinction between nothing and something is far from being clear-cut or refined. The chapter is devoted to further defining nothing, as well as something and the something-nothing continuum, in greater detail. It provides more depth, detail, and concreteness by developing each end of the continuum, and the continuum itself, through a multitude of dimensions.

papers.title: Ghost hand: My hand is not mine
papers.abstract: Abstract Synchronous visuo-tactile stimulation of the type in the rubber hand illusion (RHI)^1-3^ and in out of body experience (OBE)^4,5^ can induce the brain to incorporate external objects or images into a part or whole of body image. Whether in the context of RHI or OBE, since the participant passively receives visuo-tactile stimulations, body image appears only with the sense of ownership (SoO), not with the sense of agency (the registration that we are the initiators of our actions; SoA)^6,7^. Insofar as self-consciousness as a body image is a unity acting in its environments, body image has to be investigated in the relationship between SoO and SoA^8,9^. It requires an experimental condition in which SoO and SoA can be independently separated in an active condition. However, no experimental condition that is opposite to RHI and OBE in which a subject can feel SoA but not SoO has been proposed to date^10^. Here, we show that a person loses SoO for his own hand that he can freely move by his own will when he sees himself in a lateral view through a head mounted display. It was previously thought that SoO can be represented by synchronous inter-modal stimulations^10^, and that SoO appears to be complemented by SoA11. Our findings show that SoO can be lost under a synchronous visuo-proprioceptive condition while SoA can be maintained. SoO and SoA are two aspects of body representation, and similar dissociations have been proposed in various contexts, such as body image and body schema^12,13^, and 'Acting I' and 'Mine'^14^. Our result suggests that the two-centric-self consisting of SoA and SoO can enhance dynamically robust self-consciousness.

papers.title: Habits of Goodness
papers.abstract: I propose an ethics that is based on stories rather than rules. The things we do in our daily lives (our motor routines) do not require articulatable goals expressible in language. We develop the “good habits” that make us good people by developing/inheriting a set of prototypes, then responding to each life situation by comparing it with those prototypes. Such a multidimensional prototype system could be realized in a connectionist network embodied in a brain/body and embedded in a world. It would not require logical reasoning as such, but rather a form of skilled coping very different from anything else considered by ethical theory. Once we realize that ethical judgments are based on prototypes and stories, rather than rules and justice, we can rethink how best to empower the revolutionary changes that are now taking place in our concepts of ethics and courtesy.

papers.title: Mediterranean food pattern vs. Mediterranean diet: a necessary approach?
papers.abstract: "Food pattern" and "diet" sometimes are referred with the same meaning. "Food pattern" can be defined by a priori and a posteriori approaches and refers to the characterisation of foods and frequency of consumption within a population combining with various characteristics. "Diet" may be represented as an individual way of life and considers the food consumption and others like culture, history, society, economy, sustainability, culinary activities, conviviality, physical activity and rest. Mediterranean diet fits on these two concepts. The question is if we are measuring Mediterranean diet as a whole, or whether we are only measuring one of its parts, neglecting the rest of components. Can this compromise the way we monitor its adherence and evolution, with the possibility of losing the perception of certain aspects? How can we preserve and promote the concept if we do not monitor all the pieces of the puzzle?
papers.venue: International Journal of Food Sciences and Nutrition

papers.title: The Influence of the Inner Man on the Apparent Human Behavior (Christian Exegetical View)
papers.abstract: This working paper seeks to explain the influence of the inner man on human behavior in general and the Christian believer in particular . Because there is a complete conviction among some that the inner man (unseen) is responsible for sin -as in the case of righteousness- and it may also stem from it, since the fall into Original sin until today. If it is not directly by: heart, soul, spirit, mind with free will, then it will be through responsibility or tacit participation (by lack of prohibition or taming) for sinful behavior that may come from outside through the flesh and its senses (sight, hearing, etc.), because: The good man out of the good treasure of his heart brings forth good things, and an evil man out of the evil treasure brings forth evil things (Matt. 12:35). And this is done through the behavior of human satisfaction of needs (physical and spiritual), because the flesh lusts against the spirit, (Galatians 5:17). With taking into account all factors of the surrounding external environment -economic, social and cultural environment, etc- which is difficult to control. In confronting the believer's faith and religious convictions that affect his behavior. The study also assumes that satisfying the human needs of the believer -originally- is spiritual satisfaction and not physical, for it is written: But you are not in the flesh but in the spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God dwells in you (Romans 8:9). But this also does not prevent from being the opposite to be the correct . not only because what is born of the flesh is a flesh -John 3: 6- but also because of the negligence and weakness of the spirit and his distance from God (and all inner man). This study is complementary and explanatory to previous studies by the researcher in the same field, which also means that this study does not agree with Abraham Maslow's hierarchy of needs (1943).Although spiritual human satisfaction is difficult to deal with quantitatively -because who can be filled and satisfied from God's love and mercy- the study assumes metaphorically to simplify the explanation: that the sum of the physical and spiritual needs of a person is (100%). papers.title: 5 Object
papers.abstract: Abstract Aquinas asserts on many occasions that human actions are specified by their objects. Two meanings he gives to the term ‘object’ are particularly significant. On some occasions, he uses ‘object’ to mean a thing in so far as it possesses a formal quality by which it defines a related action, habit, or power. To illustrate, as the colour of something (not its smell or taste) defines sight, so distinctive differences in what is willed determines whether human actions are morally good, evil, or indifferent, and whether they belong to more particular moral species such as almsgiving or adultery. On other occasions, Aquinas has a second meaning for ‘object’, namely, a proximate end. In this case, when he says an object specifies, he means that a proximate end (such as ‘taking an innocent life’) determines a moral species (such as ‘murder’), and that no further end an agent may pursue (such as wealth) is necessary to make this determination.

papers.title: Generalize or Personalize - Do Dogs Transfer an Acquired Rule to Novel Situations and Persons?
papers.abstract: Recent studies have raised the question of whether dogs, like human infants, comprehend an established rule as generalizable, normative knowledge or rather as episodic information, existing only in the immediate situation. In the current study we tested whether dogs disobeyed a prohibition to take a treat (i) in the presence of the communicator of the ban, (ii) after a temporary absence of the communicator, and (iii) in the presence of a novel person. Dogs disobeyed the rule significantly more often when the communicator left the room for a moment or when they were faced with a new person, than when she stayed present in the room. These results indicate that dogs "forget" a rule as soon as the immediate human context becomes disrupted.

papers.title: Moral Traces and Relational Autonomy
papers.abstract: One feature of James Childress's approach to ethics is the experience of "moral traces" that agents ought to feel in situations of conflict after they have overridden one strong value for the sake of another.1 This experience grasps at something intuitive about the moral life, that in situations of intense moral conflict when we are faced with a choice to act in a way that goes against a deeply held value, it is morally important that we feel and respond a certain way. At the most immediate level, this might entail privately mourning or grieving that we had to violate the value. Doing so would affirm that we care about the overridden value, and by acknowledging such a care we would feel that our moral integrity has been protected. But shouldn't the concept of moral traces entail more than a private process of grief? Shouldn't it have an effect on our relations with others? Moral traces ought to obligate us to act toward others in certain ways, and in that sense it is a concept quite distinct from the pangs of conscience we feel when we have behaved badly. At the very least, these traces ought to press us to offer an explanation or justification to others for why we acted against an important moral value, especially if those others were affected negatively by our action. In more extreme cases, we might even be compelled to make amends or offer reparations to the one or ones who were harmed by our action.2In this article I am interested in sorting through the ways that moral traces function in the moral life, especially in terms of the work they do in maintaining and building social and institutional relationships. I want to suggest that moral traces are more than an internal attitude that pertains to individual flourishing; they are also integral to communal well-being. By pointing to a contrast between moral traces as important for individual flourishing and moral traces as conducive to increased communal well-being, I also hope to expand our thinking about the liberal principle of autonomy that is central to Childress's approach. I am motivated in this article by a worry that some might use the appeal to moral traces to reinforce an individualistic, psychological notion of the self. This is clearly something that Childress does not do, as can be seen in his 1970 Soundings article, "Who Shall Live When Not All Can Live?" There he tethers the equitable distribution of scarce medical resources firmly to the maintenance of relationships of trust. In later writings, he explicitly outlines the obligations to others that emerge in situations when an important value has been overridden. Relationships of trust and the obligations to others incurred by moral traces both point to a conception of agency that is relational.In what follows, I hope to suggest the broad contours of an account of moral traces that highlights its relational features. Looking at moral traces through a relational lens accentuates, and perhaps even intensifies, the obligations that they incur. Put differently, relational conceptions of autonomy require a more careful account of moral traces—one that focuses on what we owe one another. By a relational conception of autonomy, I mean a view of agency that sees the choices we make as shaped by our relations with and commitment to others. Highlighting moral traces as central to the moral life is a way to recognize the importance of human accountability, which ensures that we are always fully aware of how our actions affect others. Ultimately, the significance of the effect of moral traces does not lie simply in protecting an agent's integrity or sense of herself as morally whole but rather in how it promotes the building and maintaining of relations.Annette Baier makes this point eloquently in her critique of Michael Stocker's account of moral guilt—a concept that, while not exactly synonymous with moral traces, does share a family resemblance. She notes that although Stocker is concerned about the effects of moral dilemmas, his "attention is given to the emotions of choosers, not to the feelings of the victims or beneficiaries of their choices" (1992, 363). At another point, Baier refers to the "dirty hands" metaphor as pushing us "into a Lady Macbeth frame of mind, obsessed with our own stained character rather than what we have done to others and how that felt for them" (363).3 It is precisely this sense of how those harmed by our actions might feel that makes moral traces such a central component of a relational account of morality. Baier writes, "Without a moral psychology that puts informed empathy and willingness to listen to others' point of view squarely in the center of our moral-psychological capacities, without a social interactive account both of rationality and of morality, the constraints that moral psychology can put on what counts as 'a more acceptable version of ethics' will be merely formal and very limited" (365).While Childress does not use the term moral traces in his early Soundings article, he does offer some brief thoughts that hint at its further development in later writings. His short mention of moral guilt in this article serves as an impetus for my reflections about how moral traces can serve a relationship-building or maintaining purpose. I begin by assessing what he says in the Soundings article, especially as it relates to the view of the theologian Helmut Thielicke, whom Childress discusses in this article. I then look to Childress's discussion of moral traces in later writings on war, bioethics, and public health. Finally, as a way to further examine the relational implications of the concept, I turn to two fairly recent concepts in the bioethics literature: moral distress in nursing ethics and "the patient as victim and vector model" in public health ethics. While certainly not identical to Childress's conception of moral traces, these concepts reinforce a similar sentiment about relationality and our obligations to others in difficult moral cases. They also help us see that moral traces are not only located in the individual conscience or in the moral universe more generally; their effects are also embodied in institutional procedures.4 This echoes Childress's sentiment in the 1970 Soundings article that one of the tasks of social ethics is "to propose relatively just institutional arrangements within which self-interested and biased men can live" (Childress 1970, 342).In the 1970 article "Who Shall Live When Not All Can Live?," James Childress makes a passing reference to a concept that forms a connective tissue through the corpus of his work in areas as diverse as conscience, war, and bioethics. He suggests that the allocation of scarce lifesaving medical resources (SLMR) presents us with "'borderline situations' which inevitably involve guilt" (1970, 175). He borrows the phrase "borderline situations" from the German theologian Helmut Thielicke, who had only recently addressed the issue of allocation of scarce lifesaving resources at a symposium held in Texas. It is not fully clear in his brief discussion of Thielicke whether or not Childress believes that decisions about allocating scarce medical resources must involve guilt.5 He writes, "Even if all actions in SLMR should involve guilt, some may preserve human dignity to a greater extent than others" (347). What is clear, however, is that he distances himself from Thielicke's view that the best humans can do in the face of these borderline situations is "to understand and endure—not 'solve'" them. By contrast, Childress believes that one can make discriminating judgments using the tools of ethics so that even our choices about "who shall live when not all can live" are informed by the notion that some decisions may "preserve human dignity to a greater extent than others." For him the preservation of human dignity is achieved through a careful evaluation of the factors and norms in a given situation. Thus, whereas for Thielicke, any ethical judgment in such situations is flawed, Childress holds more optimistically that reasoned ethical judgments are possible. For both of them, however, the agent's realization that she is affected in some way by such difficult moral choices is important to her human flourishing. What is unclear in this brief reference is the nature and extent of this effect on the moral agent. Does it morally obligate her to make some sort of amends, or does it simply do its work on a psychological level in terms of ensuring that the overridden principle does not lose its potency?Thielicke's ideas about moral guilt are both deeply existential and deeply theological. For Thielicke, the guilt that results from moral dilemmas is debilitating to the point that it leaves the Christian moral agent with very few viable options. Indeed, he does not see the task of evangelical theological ethics as providing easy answers or solutions to ethical problems.6 Roman Catholic casuistry and its legalistic and naturalistic theology falls prey to this temptation. He uses the term "borderline situations" (Grenzsituation) to depict what he calls "abnormal cases," ones that involve "transitions or complications" (Thielicke 1966, 578).7 The prime example of such a situation for Christians, according to Thielicke, is when they must use the methods of their evil opponent, as in the case of the duty to fight oppressive tyrannical dictatorships. Thus the individual Christian, especially if he holds political responsibility, is "ineluctably forced into a situation in which he must act within a framework of injustice" (585). What such situations teach Christians is that the world is fallen: "man has perverted his world, and no man is exempt from sharing responsibility for this human character of his world, this demonic humanizing of the world. No man is merely the object of a conflict situation. We are all part of the human subject that helped to bring it about" (597). Thus what is communal about this guilt for Thielicke is that the difficult moral conflict serves to remind Christians of their ongoing guilt as children of Adam. The borderline situation has its "origin in a communal guilt which already stands behind our situation and which we for our part ever increase and intensify…. We are both channels and perpetrators of cosmic guilt" (602).Borderline questions, according to Thielicke, "preclude the possibility of any final answers." He writes, "The questions must remain open" (1970, 147). The impossibility of any final answers to difficult moral dilemmas is firmly grounded in certain theological presuppositions, such as human sinfulness. Thielicke understands the human condition of sin as a usurpation of man's limits—a going beyond the limits to which humans are destined. Put differently, it is that man "has placed himself in sinful contradiction to the destiny for which he was created" (154). In essence, human creativity—the ability to transform nature into culture—is always tainted by humanity's inability to accept its destiny as God's creatures. Humans are always pressing the boundaries of their creatureliness. He contrasts the Christian view that identifies suffering with human guilt and responsibility to secular ideas that attribute life's tragedy to the structures of the world. He writes, "In myth … this world which is no longer whole tends to be regarded as something given, an intact structure in which guilt and fate are inseparably interwoven. The Bible, on the contrary, looks instead at man. It sees not the structure, but this personal representative of our disjointed world" (156).Human sinfulness is not manifested in particular actions. Rather it is the very structure of human existence that is the root of human guilt. In essence, for Thielicke, there is no possible choice that a human can make in the face of any moral decision that would relieve her of this existential guilt: "It is a matter of being, not action" (164). Yet there are certain types of situations in which human decisions and human actions can bring about greater guilt. Indeed it is the experience of guilt that is a measure of the person's moral health and well-being. Like a wound that cannot be allowed to heal, the guilt one feels when making difficult moral decisions such as allocating scarce medical resources is difficult. In contrast to the utilitarian who is able to make a decision with clear-cut objective criteria, the moral person must suffer the anguish of the "impossibility of the task." Her suffering is felt in "pangs of conscience" that are "a kind of gauze placed in the wound to prevent its healing in the wrong way." Continuing with the metaphor, he insists that while the wound must not be closed, it must not be allowed to infect the moral actor: "The pus of the insoluble dilemma must have some way of escaping. Otherwise, the very humanity of the physician himself becomes infected; he succumbs to the illusion of the easy solution" (173). Only by keeping the wound open does Thielicke believe that humans can arrive at an awareness of the very essence of what it is to be human.The most obvious contrast between Thielicke and Childress in the Soundings article is that Childress's view of human guilt is not explicitly connected to theological and existential ideas about the ongoing guilt of humans before God. Thielicke's view of cosmic guilt undermines his confidence that any method of deciding how to allocate scarce lifesaving devices can ever really be justifiable. He invokes casting lots, but unlike Childress, his endorsement of it is lukewarm at best. He sees it as an unsatisfactory option but perhaps the best one humans have available to them in such a situation.There are two points from the Soundings article that are relevant to my attempt to rethink the concept of moral traces. First, while Childress's view about guilt in "borderline situations" is not explicitly developed in the article, his engagement with Thielicke is illuminating because I believe it foreshadows his later emphasis on moral traces. Thielicke's insistence that the "wound" should not infect the actor supports my contention that moral traces ought to do more than simply affect the individual; they must incur some sense of obligation to others. Second, Childress bases his strong support of random selection on the belief that it is the best option for maintaining human dignity, equality, and trust. All three of these values are, in his view, important for building and maintaining relationships. Childress is explicit about this in several places in the article. Quoting Paul Ramsey, he describes equality of opportunity "as the ethical substance of the relations of those individuals to one another"(Childress 1970, 348). In another passage, he describes trust as "an attitude of expectation about another," namely, the expectation that one will be treated with respect (349).When we turn to Childress's 1978 article on just war in Theological Studies, we begin to see the full development of the concept of moral traces. In this more extended discussion, he situates them within "the logic of prima-facie duties." Relying on the moral philosopher W. D. Ross, he argues that prima facie obligations are more binding than relative principles that function like rules of thumb, and less binding than absolute principles that can never be overridden. Thus, a prima facie obligation is "intrinsically binding, but it does not necessarily determine one's actual obligation" (1978, 430). A central component of the logic of these conflicting obligations is that "an overridden or outweighed prima-facie obligation continues to function in the situation and the course of action one adopts" (431; emphasis mine). Childress explicitly uses the phrases "moral traces" and "residual effects" in this article to describe how the outweighed obligation "continues to function."He also turns to A. C. Ewing, who specifies more clearly how the overridden obligation continues to have a hold on the moral agent. For Ewing this hold results in a "mental attitude" that evokes regret, but even more important, that ought to affect the agent's future actions. Ewing writes, "My omission to fulfill my prima facie duty to him in this case will increase the force of any prima facie obligations I may have to him as regards future actions. And even if it did not affect overt action, the existence of a prima facie obligation not to do it should always affect our mental attitude towards an action." Ewing describes the mental attitude as "a positive thing even if not translated into action" and writes further that "a good man will at least regret the violation of prima facie duties" (1959, 110). In a footnote, Childress comments that for W. D. Ross, the appropriate response to an overridden obligation is not shame or repentance but rather compunction.Childress's views about the intensity of this mental attitude after a moral conflict are not fully developed in this discussion. Yet he manages to introduce a broad array of terms to describe it: residual effects, regret, shame, repentance, compunction. He seems to favor the terms—traces and residue—that suggest a less intense effect on the moral agent. Elsewhere in the article, he claims more directly that guilt is not the appropriate emotional attitude in such cases. He supports, without fully developing, a notion of "creative regret" that he borrows from Albert R. Di Ianni (Childress 1978, 433). However, in discussing the jus ad bellum criterion of "right intention" as the maintenance of proper motives, he states "an attitude of regret, if not remorse, is appropriate when a prima-facie obligation is overridden" (438). Such a clear statement equating moral traces with regret is not typical of his discussions in later work, such as Principles of Bioethics (PBE).Nevertheless, in his view, overriding a principle does lead to specific obligations. These are most explicit in his discussion of the jus in bello criteria—the criteria that govern how to conduct war. His primary point is that even though a just war requires one to overrule the prima facie obligation not to injure or kill another, the hold that the obligation has on the moral agent is not "overruled." In other words, the agent still must discharge some obligations to the other—and these obligations require that (1) the immediate object of war is not to kill or even injure, (2) one ought not directly target noncombatants, (3) one cannot impose "unnecessary suffering," and (4) any effect (even if only indirect) of war on civilians "must be justified by the principle of proportion" (441). By connecting moral traces to the jus in bello criteria, Childress reinforces a notion that these traces are more than just an internal wound or disposition, and instead constitute an attitude that necessarily entails an obligation to minimize the harms caused by overriding a prima facie duty.When we turn our attention to Childress's later work, especially in PBE, we see that moral traces play a significant role in two ways: to remind the agent that prima facie duties are not neutral values and to highlight the centrality of conscience and integrity as virtues in the practice of medicine. The account of the logic of prima facie duties in PBE follows quite closely the account presented in the earlier just-war article. For example, Childress and his coauthor, Tom Beauchamp, argue that when overriding a prima facie obligation, there will always be traces of "regret and a sense of moral residue." They write, "Moral residue results because an overridden prima facie obligation does not simply go away when overridden" (Beauchamp and Childress 2009, 19). While overlapping in some ways with their discussion of conscience, the two concepts remain distinct. Childress describes conscience as "an internal sanction that comes into play through critical reflection." While this sanction may have different forms, he notes that it "often appears as a bad conscience—in the form of feelings of remorse, guilt, shame, disunity, or disharmony—as the individual recognizes his or her acts as wrong" (44). The sanction of a bad conscience is different from the feeling of moral traces, because with the former, the agent feels that the act she performed is wrong. Moral traces, by contrast, imply that one has "residual obligations" or that one needs to at least acknowledge internally that an important obligation or value has been sacrificed, but not that the act itself is wrong. Nevertheless, moral traces share with the conscience the ability to help repair any disunity or disharmony that the agent may have experienced in the context of the difficult dilemma.One final example of the role of moral traces in Childress's work comes from his writings on the moral foundations of public health. Along with several colleagues, he has suggested that public health officials must satisfy five justificatory conditions when choosing to override individual liberty or justice. These are effectiveness, proportionality, necessity, least infringement, and public justification. It is the last of these that I think illustrates most clearly the connection between moral traces and obligations. In particular, the public health setting provides an example of institutional obligations that result from acknowledging that an important value has been overridden. The responsibility that public officials have in this regard is "to explain and justify that infringement, whenever possible, to the relevant parties, including those affected by the infringement." They must offer moral reasons because they are required to "treat citizens as equals" (Childress et al. 2002, 173). This activity of accountability to the public is, in Childress's words, "indispensable for engendering and sustaining public trust, as well as for expressing justice." It involves actively seeking ways to engage the public with the decisions being made on its behalf. This engagement involves seeking out the public's input, maintaining transparency about the process, and providing relevant information to the public. Although Childress and his coauthors do not use the language of moral traces in this discussion of public justification, their appeal to the obligations that public authorities have when they have infringed upon or overridden important moral values is a by-product of the traces. Childress's emphasis on ongoing obligations illustrates his belief that difficult moral decisions do not come to an abrupt end; they do not disappear. Rather, responsible moral agents ought to continue to act and feel in ways that acknowledge the ongoing implications of these decisions.What can we conclude about Childress's view of moral traces from this quick summary of his work? First, it seems clear that he does not see moral traces as identical to moral regret. Individuals can experience moral traces while being sure that they made the right decision in difficult moral situation. In other words, they are not wishing that they had done something else.8 Rather, they are taking the implications of what they did seriously. Second, his view of moral traces as incurring ongoing obligations supports an account of agency that is relational. This conclusion runs counter to prevailing critiques of Childress's "principlism" that depict it as grounded in a conception of the agent as an isolated, atomistic individual.Accounts of personhood as relational have become fairly commonplace in normative ethical discussions, especially ones that are informed by feminist, virtue, narrative, or communitarian visions. The "relational self" is usually posited over against the individualistic moral agent believed to be prevalent in certain liberal philosophical approaches. This individualistic vision of autonomy is also commonly associated with bioethics discourse, especially with Childress's approach.9 Critics of autonomy worry about the tendency to see the self as independent and separate from the discursive contexts that shape our commitments and values. They think a more accurate description of moral agency is one of responsiveness to the particularities of situations and to the network of dependencies that enable individuals to flourish. While the emphasis on particularity and dependency has been appealing to many feminist theorists, some have rejected a wholesale abandonment of autonomy as potentially antithetical to feminist political goals. They are skeptical of views that mistakenly stereotype individual autonomy as fundamentally individualistic and rationalistic. Thus they want to salvage autonomy because of the central role they believe it plays in feminist analyses of oppression, subjection, and agency. The model of relational autonomy has emerged as a useful hybrid that takes the concerns raised by critics of autonomy seriously without abandoning the important function of respect for the dignity of the individual.10The principle of autonomy is clearly central to Childress's ethics. Even in the Soundings article, we can see that he supports random selection for the allocation of scarce medical resources because it preserves respect for dignity and autonomy. Yet it is important to note that for Childress this respect for autonomy does not preclude attention to relationships. Indeed, it is intimately tied to the attitudes of trust necessary for society to function. Trust provides us with one example of a deeply relational concept that is intimately tied to respect for autonomy, insofar as it reflects our ultimate respect for the other's dignity and humanity. Childress's emphasis on moral traces and the obligations they produce also supports a concept of autonomy that is attentive to human relationships. While Childress avoids pressing moral traces and regret into the stronger realms of remorse or guilt, his emphasis on residual obligations in the contexts of war, bioethics, and public health suggests that the effects of moral traces extend beyond individual conscience. They require the moral agent to attend to the impact of her act on human relationships, both private and public. This suggests that for Childress, no moral decision exists in an isolated vacuum. We cannot thus speak of individual autonomy apart from the broader social contexts that all humans inhabit. As Courtney Campbell reminds us, certain elements of Childress's theology—namely, his claims about humans created in God's image—provide the basis for a view of autonomy that goes against certain secular notions of autonomy that privilege individualism and self-determination. Childress's theologically informed view of autonomy, according to Campbell, "must be qualified by considerations of dependence, sociality, and finitude" (Campbell 1989).Moral traces result when one voluntarily makes a choice to act in a certain way, but recognizes that in one's doing so, an important moral principle or value is threatened or even sacrificed. But what about cases in which the choice to act is not completely voluntary, when the agent is constrained by institutional pressures? These cases are captured by the terms moral distress and moral residue—terms that have come to be associated primarily with nursing ethics. The discussion of these terms is not always very precise in the literature, where we often see the terms conflated. It is useful, however, to get a sense of how these concepts work and to ask whether they offer any useful insights for thinking about the relational component of moral traces.The appeal to the language of moral distress and moral residue in nursing ethics refers to a much more intense sentiment than Childress's appeal to moral traces. Indeed, at times it sounds like a radically different phenomenon—something that results from forced violations of moral values, rather than from genuinely dilemmatic situations. In that sense, it is more like situations that involve violations of conscience and integrity. Recall that in PBE, Beauchamp and Childress distinguish moral traces from conscience. Nevertheless, discussions of moral distress can show us how internal reflections about our moral choices can and should have an effect on our obligations to others. More particularly, they draw attention to the implications of moral traces on institutional structures and procedures.Jameton's pioneering article on the issue of moral distress in nursing makes an important distinction between moral dilemmas (which Childress believes gives rise to moral traces) and moral distress. Moral dilemmas occur when "it is clear to the nurse that different and important values conflict, but no choice presents itself that preserves both" (Jameton 1993, 542). In contrast, distress is what occurs when a moral agent is unable to act on a judgment as a result of institutional or professional constraints. For Jameton, moral dilemmas present interesting material for students of philosophy to ponder, but in reality, they are rare and, in his words, "are bad news and to be avoided" (543). By dismissing moral dilemmas as rare occurrences, Jameton pays little attention to the experiences of moral regret or guilt. He worries, however, that nurses often conflate or confuse dilemmas (in the philosophical sense) with the experience of moral distress. In other words, when asked to describe their experiences, nurses often characterize the distress they feel at not being able to act on their judgments as dilemmatic. Although he acknowledges that distress can and often does give rise to "second-order" moral dilemmas, it is a mistake to view situations when one's choices are constrained institutionally as dilemmatic. To do so leads nurses to unnecessarily blame themselves for situations over which they have little control. I think Jameton's point is pertinent because I take him to be saying that when nurses view their actions as resulting from genuine dilemmas instead of from unjust institutional structures, they will experience the wrong kind of guilt. What really matters for nurses is that institutions treat them justly by allowing them opportunities to participate fully in the decision-making process. Jameton is worried about the conflation of dilemmatic situations and situations of moral distress because of its implications for moral responsibility. The importance of the category of "moral distress" is that it draws attention to how nurses are often forced to act in ways that violate their deeply held beliefs and commitments. This violation leads to a significant moral crisis that can potentially paralyze the agent. In other words, unlike moral traces, moral distress does little for relationship and community building. Indeed, it leads to disintegration. The "distressed" nurse is isolated and finds herself alienated from her institutional and professional role. In the end, while the literature on moral distress often seems to be referring to something different from moral traces in the sense that Childress uses the term, it can offer us some useful insight about relationship/community building in the aftermath of difficult moral problems. In particular, it helps us to think about how moral traces in Childress's sense ought to lead to just social and institutional arrangements.Margaret Battin's recent contribution to public health ethics offers us more resources for thinking about moral traces and their relational features. She intends her work as an intervention in bioethics and public health ethics—one that attempts to undermine the notion of the self that underlies these approaches. Her approach is animated by several concerns. One has to do with a failure of bioethics to account for infectious disease as a defining feature of human experience. For Battin, this seemingly minor oversight overlooks something very important about our nature as human animals. She writes, "Infectiousness is an especially direct reminder of how misleading the paradigms of individualism can be" (Battin et al. 2009, 78). Battin's overarching goal, however, is to develop a more sensitive account of public health ethics. While she does not explicitly address the ideas of regret, remorse, or conscience, I believe her reminder about our biological reality as deeply interconnected creatures serves as a useful impetus for thinking about the implications of relational autonomy.Battin describes the self as a "way-station," and "embedded" self, a vision of subjectivity that resonates with many feminist critiques of autonomy.11 Battin's important insight is that to speak of persons as shaped and constituted by and through their webs of relations is to speak about something physical and biological. She visualizes, rather than a romantic vision of relationality as constituted merely by friendship and familial relations, the individual as a "launching pad and breeding ground for trillions of organisms that move from one human being to another, either directly or by way of intermediate vectors" (462). This biological view expands the feminist account of relational autonomy. She writes, "Attention to social locatedness is not enough. Physical locatedness … is critical as well" (78).While clinical medicine has tended to see the patient primarily as a victim, public health has seen the patient primarily as a vector. Battin urges public health and bioethics to view patients as both simultaneously, "an account in which the patient can be seen as both victim and vector at the same time, a person simultaneously occupying both morally relevant roles" (87). Another way to put this is that we need to think of ourselves not only in terms of the threats to us but also in terms of the threats we potentially pose to others. This, according to Battin, draws a more nuanced and complex picture of moral agency. In particular it complicates notions of responsibility and blame that posit that we can always know who is to blame and for what. The biological view of ourselves as victims and vectors of infectious disease acknowledges that we cannot always know with certainty who is to blame (who harms and who is harmed).This view of the self provides an interesting grounding to the notion of moral traces as a relational concept. Agents in a dilemmatic situation are never fully relieved of the traces of guilt or sorrow for what they have done, and that is a good thing. It serves as a reminder of our shared vulnerability and woundedness as human subjects. In other words, our actions have effects and the virtuous agent is sensitive to these effects. In the image of Battin's way-station self we see how we are all biologically connected in pathways of disease. In a similar way moral traces remind us of our roles as both subjects and objects.We can see the implications of Battin's metaphysical view in her treatment of the ethics of distribution of scarce medical resources in cases of pandemic emergencies. She concurs with the pandemic triage plans put forth by Canada, Tennessee, and Utah that all base their allocation decisions on "medical criteria of survivability and need" (397). However, she notes that the patient as victim and vector (PVV) perspective draws our attention to two additional points. First, these plans fail to give an adequate account of what kind of care those who are "deprioritized" receive, and second, existing injustices in health care are exacerbated by these allocation criteria. Consequently, Battin argues that the plans must be clear about the obligation they have to care for those who will not be first in the queue to receive care in such an emergency. The issue of injustice only makes clear that we have an obligation to attend to health care inequities before such emergency situations strike. These conclusions illustrate the importance of the residual obligations incurred in situations of moral conflict. Like Childress's views about the necessity of the jus in bello criteria, and about the importance of public justifications in public health, Battin affirms that overriding a principle leaves traces that are not only wounding to the moral agent but also damaging to the relationships of trust that enable communities to exist and flourish.Without a strong sense of moral traces or even moral regret, we are left with a view of an agent who is not fully accountable to others—who can override important moral norms without having to incur any costs. Moral traces acknowledge the vulnerability and limits of our humanity. Yet it would be a mistake to stop there by allowing such an acknowledgment to turn us inward by focusing exclusively on whether our integrity has been damaged. Moral traces ought to do more than just make us feel bad. They are the impetus for broadcasting our accountability to others by offering reasons for our actions. In the case of the allocation of scarce medical resources, that accountability is necessary for extending and maintaining trust between health care providers and patients. Childress argues that randomness and chance are "most in accord with this relationship of trust" (1970, 349). Decisions about who should receive lifesaving treatments based on social worth are not attentive to the long-term effects of our actions on the fundamental relationships that form the basis of our society.

papers.title: THE FREEDOM OF GOD AND THE FREEDOM OF MAN IN FATHER DUMITRU STĂNILOAE’S THEOLOGY
papers.abstract: God is the supreme Mystery of existence, He is by His own power above existence. God is the tripersonal super-essence of spiritual nature, above all spirituality that we may understand or imagine. He is the one Who brings everything into existence and that is why there is a fundamental difference between God and creation; the origin and the existence of the creation depend on the will and the creative work of God. As personal super-essence and super- existence, God is completely free because He cannot be closed into a reference system; He is the ultimate instance of all His decisions and acts. Man, created in the image of God reflects at the level of creation the freedom of God. As created existence, he is part of a reference system of the created world, which depends on God in its existence and becoming. As personal existence, in the image of God, the human person is capable of an existence that is not entirely enclosed into the reference system of the created nature; he is called to the free communion with God and it is the ultimate instance that decides his thoughts, acts and words. Man guards and increases his freedom or loses it according to the manner in which he professes it. For within the freedom of man the possibility to state the freedom is involved, at the same time renouncing it. The paradox of the freedom of man consists of the fact that man gives up his freedom through his own freedom because of pride or because he leaves the communion with God, Who offers him the true freedom.

papers.title: Werewolf in Kakania. Moosbrugger: an Analysis of His Subjectivity
papers.abstract: We are held responsible for our deeds – even if we did not act according to our will. From a third-person perspective, to be deemed ‘mad’ is to be held not responsible for one’s actions. From a first-person perspective, to be mad is to feel that one’s deeds are not one’s own, thus not responsible for them – or vice versa to feel responsible for deeds that are not one’s own. The vulnerability to madness, the cypher of condicio humana, imbues responsibility: loss of responsibility (alienation) and excess of responsibility (guilt) are the extreme polarities of the dialectics of answerability in human existence. To be human is to be at odds with responsibility, that is, with the involuntary dimension of our being. Responsibility is at the same time a presupposition and a task since society expects a person to feel responsible for her deeds; yet responsibility is not an a priori, rather an achievement to be obtained through education. As Ricouer puts it: ‘Education is education to responsibility’. It is very difficult to disentangle responsibility from non-responsibility and standard assessment procedures are not always helpful for this. Taking the literary case of Musil’s serial murderer Moosbrugger, I sketch an alternative view based on the reconstruction of the life-world in which a given action takes place – rather than on the assessment of isolated symptoms. ‘To the judge –Musil writes – Moosbrugger was a universe, and it was very hard to say something convincing about a universe”. The judicial assessment of accountability is an ‘anaemic concept‘ if it does not takes into account the person‘s ‘universe’, that is, the ontological framework in which she is posited.

papers.abstract: The human will is the main directive of human action, and upon it the reward and punishment, and endowment is one of the important aspects of the expression of the will of the one who is standing.Because endowment is one of the best acts of communion.His reward continues even after the death of the one standing, and the basic principle in the condition of the waqf is that it is obligatory to follow.Because the endowment donated money on a conditional basis, so he had his condition, and it was necessary to follow it, so it is certain that the condition of the endowment expresses his will from the endowment, and the basic principle is that the disposition of the endowment is restricted to what the endowment wants from his endowment, so it is not permissible to neglect his will, and this includes all endowment actions, such as appointing The endowment, the endowment glasses, how the endowment funds are distributed, the endowment proceeds distributed, the possibility of investing the endowment money, the maintenance of the endowment if it needs to be maintained, or selling and replacing it whenever the interest is in this, taking into account the lack of rigidity and a degree of flexibility when interpreting the will of the endowment whenever required The general legal interest of the endowment is flexible in interpreting that will, in a way that achieves the interest of the beneficiaries of the endowment, and ensures the survival of the endowment eye, and does not clash with the will of the endowment.

papers.title: There Is No Such Thing as "Inert" Matter
papers.abstract: The trend towards a universal human acceptance of the dogma that everything is inert has led humanity to various conditions of despair and depression and oppression and suppression, and vast numbers of other kinds of suffering. It is high time that this trend should be reversed, so that direct and transcendent personal experiences of Nature and Divinity are allowed to be sought out by the people, and then treasured, rather than reviled as unscientific. A science completely devoid of Consciousness is utterly incapable of predicting any event or result that involves Consciousness.

papers.title: La situación de las humanidades
papers.abstract: In tody's western societies, the humanities receive dual treatment: on the one hand, they are rendered verbal tribute as disciplines filled with aesthetic, spiritual or vital values that are lacking in other more technical and specialized disciplines; but, on the other, they are te victims of a degree of discrimination: they are not considered to be truly scientific notwithstanding the efforts -that at times are didiculous- to include curves, graphs, statistics and other abstractions in their publications. This is the result of a relatively recent development that tends to reserve the status of science only to studies that involve quantification and methematization.

papers.title: The use of “power-words” in animistic Tugen worldview in light of biblical perspectives
papers.abstract: This study sought to examine the phenomena of Power-Words which have significant power to exert control of both the physical and spiritual or invisible realm. Power-Words have power beyond the ordinary speech of communicating ideas. It is direct and does not need meditation. The study found that Power-Words are said to have inherent power to deal with all realms of life. They are used in the animistic worldview for protection, provision and treatment against the exigencies of life experienced in the physical and spiritual world. In the use of Power-Words, the findings observed that a careful application of Power-Words is needed so as to avoid a syncretistic attitude that enters the biblical worldview from an animistic worldview which presupposes the sovereignty of man where he plans what is desirable for oneself in his environment. Man becomes God for himself or becomes co-equal with God, which is a humanistic attitude of trying to achieve one's own desired goals. This is a false authority in handling and working out one's own destiny. This piece of work concludes that God cannot be manipulated in any form or any means. God will not share his glory with man; hence Power-Words used by man without acknowledging the sovereignty of God are contrary to the character and nature of God.
